Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just between your chest and abdomen is where you’ll find one of the most
important muscles you probably didn't know you had: the lower esophageal sphincter, or LES. When functioning properly, this ring of tissue plays a crucial
role in helping us eat. But when the LES malfunctions, it becomes the main player in heartburn --a searing, sometimes sour-tasting
chest-spasm that many people will experience
at some point in their lives. We know that humans have
been battling heartburn for hundreds, if not thousands of years. But recently the incidence has risen, making it a common stomach 
complaint worldwide. When the symptoms of heartburn become more
more regular and intense —such as twice a week or more-- it’s diagnosed as Gastroesophageal
Reflux Disease, or GERD. But what causes this problem, and how can it be stopped? Heartburn starts in an area called the gastroesophageal junction, 
where the LES resides. This smooth, muscular ring of the LES is moderated by an intricate 
tree of nerve roots that connect to the brain, 
the heart, and the lungs. After food enters the stomach
from the esophagus, the muscle’s task is to stop it from surging back up again. The LES contracts, squeezing 
the stomach entrance and creating a high pressure zone that prevents digestive acids 
from seeping out. But if the LES relaxes at the
wrong moment or gradually weakens, it becomes like a faulty, ill-fitting lid, causing the area to depressurize. That allows burning stomach acid-- and even chunks of food--to spurt into the esophagus, sometimes going 
as far up as the mouth. The cause of all this internal drama has long been put down to diet. Foods like caffeine and peppermint contain ingredients that may have a
relaxing affect on the LES, which makes it incapable of doing its job. Other acidic foods, 
like citrus and tomatoes, can worsen irritation of the esophagus when they leach out with stomach acid. Carbonated beverages can similarly bubble up in the stomach, forcing open the valve. But researchers have discovered
that food isn’t the only trigger. Smoking poses a risk, because the nicotine
in cigarettes relaxes the LES. Consuming excessive amounts of alcohol may have a similar effect. Pregnant women often experience
more heartburn due to the pressure of a growing baby
on their stomachs. and the levels of certain hormones 
in their bodies. Obesity can cause hernias that disrupt the anti-reflux barrier of
the gastroesophageal junction that normally protects 
against heartburn. Numerous medications, 
including those for asthma, high blood pressure, birth control, 
and depression can also have unintended 
effects on the LES. An occasional bout of heartburn isn't necessarily something to worry about. But, if heartburn starts happening regularly, it can weaken the LES muscle over time, letting more and more acid escape. And if it goes untreated, this can cause bigger problems. Over time, constant acid 
leakage from heartburn may form scar tissue which narrows the esophageal tube, making it 
harder to swallow food. Ongoing reflux can also damage the cells lining the esophagus--a rare
condition called Barrett’s esophagus, which can elevate the risk of esophageal cancer. Luckily, heartburn is often treatable with a range of medicines that can help neutralize or reduce stomach acid. In extreme cases, some people have surgery to tighten the LES to 
minimize their distress. But we can often stop heartburn before it reaches that point. Reducing the consumption 
of certain foods, not smoking, and maintaining 
a healthy weight can all dramatically reduce reflux. With proper care we can 
help our LES’s keep the chemical fountain of 
our stomachs in proper order and avoid having to feel the burn.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The most commonly reported form of reflux is
Options: A. Acid reflux, B. Alkaline reflux, C. Weakly acid or mixed acid reflux, D. Prolonged acid reflux with punctuated moments of alkaline reflux
Correct Option: A

Question 2: What is the primary function of the LES when functioning properly? Options: A. To relax the stomach entrance, B. To allow food to enter the stomach, C. To prevent digestive acids from seeping out, D. To contract and create a high pressure zone Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the condition diagnosed when the symptoms of heartburn become regular and intense? Options: A. Heartburn, B. Acid reflux, C. Stomach discomfort, D. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) Correct Option: D
Question 4: What can cause the LES to relax at the wrong moment or weaken? Options: A. Diet and food, B. Smoking and nicotine, C. Obesity and hernias, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the effect of consuming excessive amounts of alcohol on the LES? Options: A. It tightens the LES, B. It has no effect on the LES, C. It increases the pressure zone, D. It relaxes the LES Correct Option: D
Question 6: Why do pregnant women often experience more heartburn? Options: A. Due to the levels of certain hormones in their bodies, B. Due to a combination of both A and the pressure of a growing baby on their stomachs, C. Due to a different reason, D. Due to the pressure of a growing baby on their stomachs Correct Option: B
Question 7: What can happen if heartburn is left untreated? Options: A. The LES muscle becomes stronger, B. The esophageal tube becomes wider, C. The cells lining the esophagus become damaged, D. The symptoms of heartburn disappear Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Spindly trees, rusted gates, crumbling stone, a solitary mourner— these things come to mind 
when we think of cemeteries. But not so long ago, many burial grounds were lively places, with blooming gardens and crowds of people strolling among the headstones. How did our cemeteries 
become what they are today? Some have been around for centuries, like the world’s largest, Wadi al-Salaam, where more than five million 
people are buried. But most of the places we’d recognize 
as cemeteries are much younger. In fact, for much of human history, we didn’t bury our dead at all. Our ancient ancestors had many other ways 
of parting with the dead loved ones. Some were left in caves, others in trees or on mountaintops. Still others were sunk in lakes, put out to sea, ritually cannibalized, or cremated. All of these practices, though some may seem strange today, were ways of venerating the dead. By contrast, the first known burials about 120,000 years ago were likely reserved for transgressors, excluding them from the usual rites intended to honor the dead. But the first burials revealed some
advantages over other practices: they protected bodies from scavengers 
and the elements, while shielding loved ones from the 
sight of decay. These benefits may have shifted 
ancient people’s thinking toward graves designed to honor the dead, and burial became more common. Sometimes, these graves contained 
practical or ritual objects, suggesting belief in an afterlife Communal burials first appeared in North 
Africa and West Asia around 10 to 15,000 years ago, around the same time as the first 
permanent settlements in these areas. These burial grounds created permanent 
places to commemorate the dead. The nomadic Scythians littered the steppes with grave mounds known as kurgans. The Etruscans built expansive necropoles, their grid-patterned streets 
lined with tombs. In Rome, subterranean catacombs housed both cremation urns and intact remains. The word cemetery, or “sleeping chamber,” was first used by ancient Greeks, who built tombs in graveyards at the edges of their cities. In medieval European cities, Christian churchyards provided 
rare, open spaces that accommodated the dead, but also hosted markets, fairs, 
and other events. Farmers even grazed cattle in them, believing graveyard grass made 
for sweeter milk. As cities grew during the industrial 
revolution, large suburban cemeteries replaced 
smaller urban churchyards. Cemeteries like the 110-acre 
Père-Lachaise in Paris or the 72-acre Mt. Auburn 
in Cambridge, Massachusetts were lushly landscaped gardens filled with sculpted stones and ornate tombs. Once a luxury reserved for the rich 
and powerful, individually marked graves became available to the middle 
and working classes. People visited cemeteries for funerals, but also for anniversaries, holidays, or simply an afternoon outdoors. By the late 19th century, as more public 
parks and botanical gardens appeared, cemeteries began to lose visitors. Today, many old cemeteries are 
lonely places. Some are luring visitors back with tours, concerts, and other attractions. But even as we revive old cemeteries, we’re rethinking the future of burial. Cities like London, New York, and 
Hong Kong are running out of burial space. Even in places where space isn’t so tight, cemeteries permanently occupy land that can’t be otherwise cultivated 
or developed. Traditional burial consumes materials like metal, stone, and concrete, and can pollute soil and groundwater with toxic chemicals. With increasing awareness of the 
environmental costs, people are seeking alternatives. Many are turning to cremation and 
related practices. Along with these more conventional 
practices, people can now have their remains 
shot into space, used to fertilize a tree, or made into jewelry, fireworks, and even tattoo ink. In the future, options like these may 
replace burial completely. Cemeteries may be our most familiar 
monuments to the departed, but they’re just one step in our ever-evolving process of remembering and honoring the dead.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The word “cemetery” is
Options: A. Latin for “city of the dead”, B. Greek for “sleeping chamber”, C. Aramaic for “field of ashes”, D. Scythian for “resting place”
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary purpose of the first known burials about 120,000 years ago? Options: A. To honor the dead, B. To exclude transgressors from the usual rites, C. To protect bodies from scavengers and the elements, D. To create permanent places to commemorate the dead Correct Option: C
Question 2: Where did communal burials first appear around 10 to 15,000 years ago? Options: A. Europe, B. North Africa and West Asia, C. South America, D. Australia Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the name of the world's largest cemetery, where more than five million people are buried? Options: A. Wadi al-Salaam, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Mt. Auburn, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the primary reason for the decline of cemetery visits in the late 19th century? Options: A. The rise of Christianity, B. The growth of cities during the industrial revolution, C. The appearance of more public parks and botanical gardens, D. The increase in cremation practices Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the cemetery in Paris that is a 110-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Père-Lachaise, B. Mt. Auburn, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the practice of ritually cannibalizing the dead? Options: A. A common practice in ancient times, B. A practice exclusive to the Scythians, C. A practice used to honor the dead, D. A practice used to exclude transgressors Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the Scythians' grave mounds known as? Options: A. Kurgans, B. Necropoles, C. Catacombs, D. Tombs Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the primary reason for the growth of large suburban cemeteries during the industrial revolution? Options: A. The rise of Christianity, B. The growth of cities, C. The increase in cremation practices, D. The decrease in churchyard space Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the cemetery in Cambridge, Massachusetts that is a 72-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Mt. Auburn, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is one of the alternative practices to traditional burial that people are turning to? Options: A. Cremation, B. Burial at sea, C. Cremation and related practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the topic and intent, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match for the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 3 is the closest match, but only because it mentions a specific term related to cemeteries (Wadi al-Salaam), and the ground truth MCQ asks about the origin of the word "cemetery". But the question intent and options are still quite different.

A better approach would be to generate new MCQs that directly address the origin and meaning of the word "cemetery", and then try to find a match.

If I had to provide an index, I would say: 3 (but with the caveat that it's not a good match).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

when we think of cemeteries. But not so long ago, many burial grounds were lively places, with blooming gardens and crowds of people strolling among the headstones. How did our cemeteries

revolution, large suburban cemeteries replaced 
smaller urban churchyards. Cemeteries like the 110-acre 
Père-Lachaise in Paris or the 72-acre Mt. Auburn 
in Cambridge, Massachusetts were lushly landscaped gardens filled with sculpted stones and ornate tombs. Once a luxury reserved for the rich 
and powerful, individually marked graves became available to the middle 
and working classes. People visited cemeteries for funerals, but also for anniversaries, holidays, or simply an afternoon outdoors. By the late 19th century, as more public 
parks and botanical gardens appeared, cemeteries began to lose visitors. Today, many old cemeteries are 
lonely places. Some are luring visitors back with tours, concerts, and other attractions. But even as we revive old cemeteries, we’re rethinking the future of burial. Cities like London, New York, and 
Hong Kong are running out of burial space. Even in places where space isn’t so tight, cemeteries permanently occupy land that can’t be otherwise cultivated 
or developed. Traditional burial consumes materials like metal, stone, and concrete, and can pollute soil and groundwater with toxic chemicals. With increasing awareness of the 
environmental costs, people are seeking alternatives. Many are turning to cremation and 
related practices. Along with these more conventional 
practices, people can now have their remains 
shot into space, used to fertilize a tree, or made into jewelry, fireworks, and even tattoo ink. In the future, options like these may 
replace burial completely. Cemeteries may be our most familiar 
monuments to the departed, but they’re just one step in our ever-evolving process of remembering and honoring the dead.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The world’s largest cemetery is
Options: A. Pere Lachaise, France, 2.5 million +/-, B. Mt. Auburn, USA, 850,000 +/-, C. Wadi-al-Salaam, Iraq, 5 million+, D. Arlington National, USA, 7.5 million+
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary purpose of the first known burials about 120,000 years ago? Options: A. To honor the dead, B. To exclude transgressors from the usual rites, C. To protect bodies from scavengers and the elements, D. To create permanent places to commemorate the dead Correct Option: C
Question 2: Where did communal burials first appear around 10 to 15,000 years ago? Options: A. Europe, B. North Africa and West Asia, C. South America, D. Australia Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the name of the world's largest cemetery, where more than five million people are buried? Options: A. Wadi al-Salaam, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Mt. Auburn, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the primary reason for the decline of cemetery visits in the late 19th century? Options: A. The rise of Christianity, B. The growth of cities during the industrial revolution, C. The appearance of more public parks and botanical gardens, D. The increase in cremation practices Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the cemetery in Paris that is a 110-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Père-Lachaise, B. Mt. Auburn, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the practice of ritually cannibalizing the dead? Options: A. A common practice in ancient times, B. A practice exclusive to the Scythians, C. A practice used to honor the dead, D. A practice used to exclude transgressors Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the Scythians' grave mounds known as? Options: A. Kurgans, B. Necropoles, C. Catacombs, D. Tombs Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the primary reason for the growth of large suburban cemeteries during the industrial revolution? Options: A. The rise of Christianity, B. The growth of cities, C. The increase in cremation practices, D. The decrease in churchyard space Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the cemetery in Cambridge, Massachusetts that is a 72-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Mt. Auburn, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is one of the alternative practices to traditional burial that people are turning to? Options: A. Cremation, B. Burial at sea, C. Cremation and related practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Question 3: What was the name of the world's largest cemetery, where more than five million people are buried? Options: A. Wadi al-Salaam, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Mt. Auburn, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the world's largest cemetery, and both have Wadi al-Salaam as the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Spindly trees, rusted gates, crumbling stone, a solitary mourner— these things come to mind 
when we think of cemeteries. But not so long ago, many burial grounds were lively places, with blooming gardens and crowds of people strolling among the headstones. How did our cemeteries 
become what they are today? Some have been around for centuries, like the world’s largest, Wadi al-Salaam, where more than five million 
people are buried. But most of the places we’d recognize 
as cemeteries are much younger. In fact, for much of human history, we didn’t bury our dead at all. Our ancient ancestors had many other ways 
of parting with the dead loved ones. Some were left in caves, others in trees or on mountaintops. Still others were sunk in lakes, put out to sea, ritually cannibalized, or cremated. All of these practices, though some may seem strange today, were ways of venerating the dead. By contrast, the first known burials about 120,000 years ago were likely reserved for transgressors, excluding them from the usual rites intended to honor the dead. But the first burials revealed some
advantages over other practices: they protected bodies from scavengers 
and the elements, while shielding loved ones from the 
sight of decay. These benefits may have shifted 
ancient people’s thinking toward graves designed to honor the dead, and burial became more common. Sometimes, these graves contained 
practical or ritual objects, suggesting belief in an afterlife Communal burials first appeared in North 
Africa and West Asia around 10 to 15,000 years ago, around the same time as the first 
permanent settlements in these areas. These burial grounds created permanent 
places to commemorate the dead. The nomadic Scythians littered the steppes with grave mounds known as kurgans. The Etruscans built expansive necropoles, their grid-patterned streets 
lined with tombs. In Rome, subterranean catacombs housed both cremation urns and intact remains. The word cemetery, or “sleeping chamber,” was first used by ancient Greeks, who built tombs in graveyards at the edges of their cities. In medieval European cities, Christian churchyards provided 
rare, open spaces that accommodated the dead, but also hosted markets, fairs, 
and other events. Farmers even grazed cattle in them, believing graveyard grass made 
for sweeter milk. As cities grew during the industrial 
revolution, large suburban cemeteries replaced 
smaller urban churchyards. Cemeteries like the 110-acre 
Père-Lachaise in Paris or the 72-acre Mt. Auburn 
in Cambridge, Massachusetts were lushly landscaped gardens filled with sculpted stones and ornate tombs. Once a luxury reserved for the rich 
and powerful, individually marked graves became available to the middle 
and working classes. People visited cemeteries for funerals, but also for anniversaries, holidays, or simply an afternoon outdoors. By the late 19th century, as more public 
parks and botanical gardens appeared, cemeteries began to lose visitors. Today, many old cemeteries are 
lonely places. Some are luring visitors back with tours, concerts, and other attractions. But even as we revive old cemeteries, we’re rethinking the future of burial. Cities like London, New York, and 
Hong Kong are running out of burial space. Even in places where space isn’t so tight, cemeteries permanently occupy land that can’t be otherwise cultivated 
or developed. Traditional burial consumes materials like metal, stone, and concrete, and can pollute soil and groundwater with toxic chemicals. With increasing awareness of the 
environmental costs, people are seeking alternatives. Many are turning to cremation and 
related practices. Along with these more conventional 
practices, people can now have their remains 
shot into space, used to fertilize a tree, or made into jewelry, fireworks, and even tattoo ink. In the future, options like these may 
replace burial completely. Cemeteries may be our most familiar 
monuments to the departed, but they’re just one step in our ever-evolving process of remembering and honoring the dead.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The likely purpose of the earliest earth burials was
Options: A. To punish transgressors, B. To honor great leaders, C. To protect bodies from decomposition, D. To protect the feelings of survivors.
Correct Option: A

The appearance of more public parks and botanical gardens, D. The increase in cremation practices Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the cemetery in Paris that is a 110-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Père-Lachaise, B. Mt. Auburn, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the practice of ritually cannibalizing the dead? Options: A. A common practice in ancient times, B. A practice exclusive to the Scythians, C. A practice used to honor the dead, D. A practice used to exclude transgressors Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the Scythians' grave mounds known as? Options: A. Kurgans, B. Necropoles, C. Catacombs, D. Tombs Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the primary reason for the growth of large suburban cemeteries during the industrial revolution? Options: A. The rise of Christianity, B. The growth of cities, C. The increase in cremation practices, D. The decrease in churchyard space Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the cemetery in Cambridge, Massachusetts that is a 72-acre lushly landscaped garden? Options: A. Mt. Auburn, B. Père-Lachaise, C. Wadi al-Salaam, D. Rome's Catacombs Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is one of the alternative practices to traditional burial that people are turning to? Options: A. Cremation, B. Burial at sea, C. Cremation and related practices, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

The ground truth MCQ asks about the likely purpose of the earliest earth burials, and Question 1 asks about the primary purpose of the first known burials. Both questions are inquiring about the purpose of early burials, which makes them similar in intent and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5

**Transcript**:
Spindly trees, rusted gates, crumbling stone, a solitary mourner— these things come to mind 
when we think of cemeteries. But not so long ago, many burial grounds were lively places, with blooming gardens and crowds of people strolling among the headstones. How did our cemeteries 
become what they are today? Some have been around for centuries, like the world’s largest, Wadi al-Salaam, where more than five million 
people are buried. But most of the places we’d recognize 
as cemeteries are much younger. In fact, for much of human history, we didn’t bury our dead at all. Our ancient ancestors had many other ways 
of parting with the dead loved ones. Some were left in caves, others in trees or on mountaintops. Still others were sunk in lakes, put out to sea, ritually cannibalized, or cremated. and the elements, while shielding loved ones from the

practical or ritual objects, suggesting belief in an afterlife Communal burials first appeared in North

replace burial completely. Cemeteries may be our most familiar 
monuments to the departed, but they’re just one step in our ever-evolving process of remembering and honoring the dead.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the summer of 1895, 
crowds flooded the Coney Island boardwalk to see the latest marvel 
of roller coaster technology: the Flip Flap Railway. This was America’s first-ever looping coaster – but its thrilling flip came at a price. The ride caused numerous cases of 
severe whiplash, neck injury and even ejections, all due to its signature loop. Today, coasters can pull off 
far more exciting tricks, without resorting to the “thrill” 
of a hospital visit. But what exactly are roller coasters 
doing to your body, and how have they managed to get scarier
and safer at the same time? At the center of every roller coaster 
design is gravity. Unlike cars or transit trains, most coasters are propelled around their tracks almost entirely by gravitational energy. After the coaster crests the initial lift hill, it begins an expertly engineered cycle – building potential energy on ascents
and expending kinetic energy on descents. This rhythm repeats throughout the ride, acting out the coaster engineer’s
choreographed dance of gravitational energy. But there’s a key variable in this cycle
that wasn’t always so carefully considered: you. In the days of the Flip-Flap, ride designers were most concerned 
with coasters getting stuck somewhere along the track. This led early builders to overcompensate, hurling trains down hills and pulling on the brakes 
when they reached the station. But as gravity affects the cars, 
it also affects the passengers. And under the intense conditions
of a coaster, gravity’s effects are multiplied. There’s a common unit used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers called “g force”. One G force is the familiar tug of gravity
you feel when standing on Earth – this is the force of Earth’s 
gravitational pull on our bodies. But as riders accelerate and decelerate, they experience more or less 
gravitational force. Modern ride designers know that the 
body can handle up to roughly 5 Gs, but the Flip-Flap and its contemporaries 
routinely reached up to 12 Gs. At those levels of gravitational pressure, blood is sent flying from your brain
to your feet, leading to light-headedness or blackouts as the brain struggles to stay conscious. And oxygen deprivation in the retinal cells
impairs their ability to process light, causing greyed out vision or temporary blindness. If the riders are upside down,
blood can flood the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision
called a “redout”. Conversely, negative G’s 
create weightlessness. Within the body, short-term weightlessness
is mostly harmless. It can contribute to a rider’s 
motion sickness by suspending the fluid in 
their inner ears which coordinates balance. But the bigger potential danger – and thrill – comes from what ride designers 
call airtime. This is when riders typically
experience seat separation, and, without the proper precautions, ejection. The numerous belts and harnesses 
of modern coasters have largely solved this issue, but the passenger’s ever-changing position
can make it difficult to determine what needs to be 
strapped down. Fortunately, modern ride designers
are well aware of what your body, and the coaster, can handle. Coaster engineers play these competing 
forces against each other, to relieve periods of intense pressure
with periods of no pressure at all. And since a quick transition from 
positive to negative G-force can result in whiplash, headaches, 
and back and neck pain, they avoid the extreme changes
in speed and direction so common in thrill rides of old. Modern rides are also much sturdier, closely considering the amount
of gravity they need to withstand. At 5 G’s, your body feels 5 times heavier; so if you weigh 100lbs, you’d exert the weight of 500 lbs
on the coaster. Engineers have to account for 
the multiplied weight of every passenger when designing 
a coaster’s supports. Still, these rides aren’t for everyone. The floods of adrenaline, 
light-headedness, and motion sickness aren’t going anywhere soon. But today’s redundant restraints, 
3D modeling and simulation software have made roller coasters safer 
and more thrilling than ever. Our precise knowledge about the 
limits of the human body have helped us build coasters that are 
faster, taller, and loopier – and all without going off the rails.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Americas first looping roller coaster, the Flip-Flap Railway, was unveiled at the Coney Island Boardwalk in the summer of 1895.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the first-ever looping coaster in America? Options: A. The Flip Flap Railway, B. The Looping Coaster, C. The Gravity Coaster, D. The Thrill Ride Correct Option: A
Question 2: What unit is used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers to measure gravitational force? Options: A. Newtons, B. G force, C. Gravity units, D. Force meters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term used to describe the sensation of weightlessness experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Airtime, B. Redout, C. Weightlessness, D. Negative G Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the potential danger of airtime in a roller coaster? Options: A. Ejection, B. Whiplash, C. Headaches, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the sensation of blood flooding the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision? Options: A. Redout, B. Weightlessness, C. Airtime, D. Negative G Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? Options: A. To create a smoother ride, B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, C. To increase the G force, D. To decrease the G force Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term used to describe the fluid in the inner ears that coordinates balance? Options: A. Ear fluid, B. Balance fluid, C. Inner ear fluid, D. Vestibular fluid Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the main factor that determines the amount of gravitational force experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Speed, B. Height, C. Gravity, D. G force Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the term used to describe the redundant restraints, 3D modeling, and simulation software used to make roller coasters safer and more thrilling? Options: A. Safety features, B. Thrill features, C. Redundant restraints, D. Modern ride design Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "What was the name of the first-ever looping coaster in America?" 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it asks about the name of America's first looping roller coaster, which is the Flip-Flap Railway. Although the question format is different (multiple-choice vs. true/false), the intent and topic are the same.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the summer of 1895, 
crowds flooded the Coney Island boardwalk to see the latest marvel 
of roller coaster technology: the Flip Flap Railway. This was America’s first-ever looping coaster – but its thrilling flip came at a price. The ride caused numerous cases of

of a hospital visit. But what exactly are roller coasters

experience seat separation, and, without the proper precautions, ejection. The numerous belts and harnesses

can make it difficult to determine what needs to be 
strapped down. Fortunately, modern ride designers

and more thrilling than ever. Our precise knowledge about the 
limits of the human body have helped us build coasters that are 
faster, taller, and loopier – and all without going off the rails.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following passenger carrying devices moves by converting potential energy into kinetic energy?
Options: A. Automobile, B. Airplane, C. Roller Coaster, D. Train
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What unit is used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers to measure gravitational force? Options: A. Newtons, B. G force, C. Gravity units, D. Force meters Correct Option: B

Question 6: What is the term used to describe the sensation of blood flooding the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision? Options: A. Redout, B. Weightlessness, C. Airtime, D. Negative G Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? Options: A. To create a smoother ride, B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, C. To increase the G force, D. To decrease the G force Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the summer of 1895, 
crowds flooded the Coney Island boardwalk to see the latest marvel 
of roller coaster technology: the Flip Flap Railway. This was America’s first-ever looping coaster – but its thrilling flip came at a price. The ride caused numerous cases of 
severe whiplash, neck injury and even ejections, all due to its signature loop. Today, coasters can pull off 
far more exciting tricks, without resorting to the “thrill” 
of a hospital visit. But what exactly are roller coasters 
doing to your body, and how have they managed to get scarier
and safer at the same time? At the center of every roller coaster 
design is gravity. Unlike cars or transit trains, most coasters are propelled around their tracks almost entirely by gravitational energy. After the coaster crests the initial lift hill, it begins an expertly engineered cycle – building potential energy on ascents
and expending kinetic energy on descents. This rhythm repeats throughout the ride, acting out the coaster engineer’s
choreographed dance of gravitational energy. But there’s a key variable in this cycle
that wasn’t always so carefully considered: you. In the days of the Flip-Flap, ride designers were most concerned 
with coasters getting stuck somewhere along the track. This led early builders to overcompensate, hurling trains down hills and pulling on the brakes 
when they reached the station. But as gravity affects the cars, 
it also affects the passengers. And under the intense conditions
of a coaster, gravity’s effects are multiplied. There’s a common unit used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers called “g force”. One G force is the familiar tug of gravity
you feel when standing on Earth – this is the force of Earth’s 
gravitational pull on our bodies. But as riders accelerate and decelerate, they experience more or less 
gravitational force. Modern ride designers know that the 
body can handle up to roughly 5 Gs, but the Flip-Flap and its contemporaries 
routinely reached up to 12 Gs. At those levels of gravitational pressure, blood is sent flying from your brain
to your feet, leading to light-headedness or blackouts as the brain struggles to stay conscious. And oxygen deprivation in the retinal cells
impairs their ability to process light, causing greyed out vision or temporary blindness. If the riders are upside down,
blood can flood the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision
called a “redout”. Conversely, negative G’s 
create weightlessness. Within the body, short-term weightlessness
is mostly harmless. It can contribute to a rider’s 
motion sickness by suspending the fluid in 
their inner ears which coordinates balance. But the bigger potential danger – and thrill – comes from what ride designers 
call airtime. This is when riders typically
experience seat separation, and, without the proper precautions, ejection. The numerous belts and harnesses 
of modern coasters have largely solved this issue, but the passenger’s ever-changing position
can make it difficult to determine what needs to be 
strapped down. Fortunately, modern ride designers
are well aware of what your body, and the coaster, can handle. Coaster engineers play these competing 
forces against each other, to relieve periods of intense pressure
with periods of no pressure at all. And since a quick transition from 
positive to negative G-force can result in whiplash, headaches, 
and back and neck pain, they avoid the extreme changes
in speed and direction so common in thrill rides of old. Modern rides are also much sturdier, closely considering the amount
of gravity they need to withstand. At 5 G’s, your body feels 5 times heavier; so if you weigh 100lbs, you’d exert the weight of 500 lbs
on the coaster. Engineers have to account for 
the multiplied weight of every passenger when designing 
a coaster’s supports. Still, these rides aren’t for everyone. The floods of adrenaline, 
light-headedness, and motion sickness aren’t going anywhere soon. But today’s redundant restraints, 
3D modeling and simulation software have made roller coasters safer 
and more thrilling than ever. Our precise knowledge about the 
limits of the human body have helped us build coasters that are 
faster, taller, and loopier – and all without going off the rails.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is the gravitational pull experienced by a person standing on Earth’s surface while waiting on line for a roller coaster ride?
Options: A. Negative 1-G, B. Positive 1-G, C. Positive 5-Gs, D. Positive 12-Gs
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the first-ever looping coaster in America? Options: A. The Flip Flap Railway, B. The Looping Coaster, C. The Gravity Coaster, D. The Thrill Ride Correct Option: A
Question 2: What unit is used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers to measure gravitational force? Options: A. Newtons, B. G force, C. Gravity units, D. Force meters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term used to describe the sensation of weightlessness experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Airtime, B. Redout, C. Weightlessness, D. Negative G Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the potential danger of airtime in a roller coaster? Options: A. Ejection, B. Whiplash, C. Headaches, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the sensation of blood flooding the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision? Options: A. Redout, B. Weightlessness, C. Airtime, D. Negative G Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? Options: A. To create a smoother ride, B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, C. To increase the G force, D. To decrease the G force Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term used to describe the fluid in the inner ears that coordinates balance? Options: A. Ear fluid, B. Balance fluid, C. Inner ear fluid, D. Vestibular fluid Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the main factor that determines the amount of gravitational force experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Speed, B. Height, C. Gravity, D. G force Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the term used to describe the redundant restraints, 3D modeling, and simulation software used to make roller coasters safer and more thrilling? Options: A. Safety features, B. Thrill features, C. Redundant restraints, D. Modern ride design Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A.

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the maximum amount of gravitational force the human body can handle, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about the gravitational pull experienced by a person standing on Earth's surface.

A more similar question would be one that asks about the gravitational pull experienced by a person standing on Earth's surface, which is 1 G. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

But if I had to choose the most similar one, I would say it's Question 3, but with the understanding that it's not an exact match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

limits of the human body have helped us build coasters that are 
faster, taller, and loopier – and all without going off the rails.

Correct Option: E

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A quick transition from a positive to negative G-force can result in headaches, back and neck pain, and whiplash.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the first-ever looping coaster in America? Options: A. The Flip Flap Railway, B. The Looping Coaster, C. The Gravity Coaster, D. The Thrill Ride Correct Option: A
Question 2: What unit is used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers to measure gravitational force? Options: A. Newtons, B. G force, C. Gravity units, D. Force meters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term used to describe the sensation of weightlessness experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Airtime, B. Redout, C. Weightlessness, D. Negative G Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the potential danger of airtime in a roller coaster? Options: A. Ejection, B. Whiplash, C. Headaches, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the sensation of blood flooding the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision? Options: A. Redout, B. Weightlessness, C. Airtime, D. Negative G Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? Options: A. To create a smoother ride, B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, C. To increase the G force, D. To decrease the G force Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term used to describe the fluid in the inner ears that coordinates balance? Options: A. Ear fluid, B. Balance fluid, C. Inner ear fluid, D. Vestibular fluid Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the main factor that determines the amount of gravitational force experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Speed, B. Height, C. Gravity, D. G force Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the term used to describe the redundant restraints, 3D modeling, and simulation software used to make roller coasters safer and more thrilling? Options: A. Safety features, B. Thrill features, C. Redundant restraints, D. Modern ride design Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content and intent, as it addresses the potential negative effects of a quick transition from positive to negative G-force, which is the main idea of the ground truth MCQ. 

The correct option for Question 7 is B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, which aligns with the statement in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the summer of 1895, 
crowds flooded the Coney Island boardwalk to see the latest marvel 
of roller coaster technology: the Flip Flap Railway. This was America’s first-ever looping coaster – but its thrilling flip came at a price. The ride caused numerous cases of 
severe whiplash, neck injury and even ejections, all due to its signature loop. Today, coasters can pull off 
far more exciting tricks, without resorting to the “thrill” 
of a hospital visit. But what exactly are roller coasters 
doing to your body, and how have they managed to get scarier
and safer at the same time? At the center of every roller coaster 
design is gravity. Unlike cars or transit trains, most coasters are propelled around their tracks almost entirely by gravitational energy. After the coaster crests the initial lift hill, it begins an expertly engineered cycle – building potential energy on ascents
and expending kinetic energy on descents. This rhythm repeats throughout the ride, acting out the coaster engineer’s
choreographed dance of gravitational energy. But there’s a key variable in this cycle
that wasn’t always so carefully considered: you. In the days of the Flip-Flap, ride designers were most concerned 
with coasters getting stuck somewhere along the track. This led early builders to overcompensate, hurling trains down hills and pulling on the brakes 
when they reached the station. But as gravity affects the cars, 
it also affects the passengers. And under the intense conditions
of a coaster, gravity’s effects are multiplied. There’s a common unit used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers called “g force”. One G force is the familiar tug of gravity
you feel when standing on Earth – this is the force of Earth’s 
gravitational pull on our bodies. But as riders accelerate and decelerate, they experience more or less 
gravitational force. Modern ride designers know that the 
body can handle up to roughly 5 Gs, but the Flip-Flap and its contemporaries 
routinely reached up to 12 Gs. At those levels of gravitational pressure, blood is sent flying from your brain
to your feet, leading to light-headedness or blackouts as the brain struggles to stay conscious. And oxygen deprivation in the retinal cells
impairs their ability to process light, causing greyed out vision or temporary blindness. If the riders are upside down,
blood can flood the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision
called a “redout”. Conversely, negative G’s 
create weightlessness. Within the body, short-term weightlessness
is mostly harmless. It can contribute to a rider’s 
motion sickness by suspending the fluid in 
their inner ears which coordinates balance. But the bigger potential danger – and thrill – comes from what ride designers 
call airtime. This is when riders typically
experience seat separation, and, without the proper precautions, ejection. The numerous belts and harnesses 
of modern coasters have largely solved this issue, but the passenger’s ever-changing position
can make it difficult to determine what needs to be 
strapped down. Fortunately, modern ride designers
are well aware of what your body, and the coaster, can handle. Coaster engineers play these competing 
forces against each other, to relieve periods of intense pressure
with periods of no pressure at all. And since a quick transition from 
positive to negative G-force can result in whiplash, headaches, 
and back and neck pain, they avoid the extreme changes
in speed and direction so common in thrill rides of old. Modern rides are also much sturdier, closely considering the amount
of gravity they need to withstand. At 5 G’s, your body feels 5 times heavier; so if you weigh 100lbs, you’d exert the weight of 500 lbs
on the coaster. Engineers have to account for 
the multiplied weight of every passenger when designing 
a coaster’s supports. Still, these rides aren’t for everyone. The floods of adrenaline, 
light-headedness, and motion sickness aren’t going anywhere soon. But today’s redundant restraints, 
3D modeling and simulation software have made roller coasters safer 
and more thrilling than ever. Our precise knowledge about the 
limits of the human body have helped us build coasters that are 
faster, taller, and loopier – and all without going off the rails.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: During a roller coaster ride, if you weigh 175 pounds and experience 5-Gs, how heavy will you feel as a result of Earth’s gravitational pull while on the roller coaster?
Options: A. 175 pounds, B. 350 pounds, C. 525 pounds, D. 740 pounds, E. 875 pounds
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the first-ever looping coaster in America? Options: A. The Flip Flap Railway, B. The Looping Coaster, C. The Gravity Coaster, D. The Thrill Ride Correct Option: A
Question 2: What unit is used by jet pilots, astronauts, and coaster designers to measure gravitational force? Options: A. Newtons, B. G force, C. Gravity units, D. Force meters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term used to describe the sensation of weightlessness experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Airtime, B. Redout, C. Weightlessness, D. Negative G Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the potential danger of airtime in a roller coaster? Options: A. Ejection, B. Whiplash, C. Headaches, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the sensation of blood flooding the skull, causing a bout of crimson vision? Options: A. Redout, B. Weightlessness, C. Airtime, D. Negative G Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main reason why roller coaster designers avoid extreme changes in speed and direction? Options: A. To create a smoother ride, B. To avoid whiplash, headaches, and back and neck pain, C. To increase the G force, D. To decrease the G force Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term used to describe the fluid in the inner ears that coordinates balance? Options: A. Ear fluid, B. Balance fluid, C. Inner ear fluid, D. Vestibular fluid Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the main factor that determines the amount of gravitational force experienced by riders in a roller coaster? Options: A. Speed, B. Height, C. Gravity, D. G force Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the term used to describe the redundant restraints, 3D modeling, and simulation software used to make roller coasters safer and more thrilling? Options: A. Safety features, B. Thrill features, C. Redundant restraints, D. Modern ride design Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but it is related to the concept of G-force and its effect on the human body.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 3: What is the maximum amount of gravitational force that the human body can handle? Options: A. 5 Gs, B. 10 Gs, C. 12 Gs, D. 15 Gs Correct Option: A

However, this question does not directly ask about the effect of 5-Gs on a person's weight. 

A more relevant question that could match the ground truth MCQ would be one that asks about the effect of G-force on a person's weight, but such a question is not present in the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would choose Question 3, but with the understanding that it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the kingdom’s
most prosperous merchants has been exposed for his corrupt dealings. Nearly all of his riches are invested in a collection of 30 exquisite Burmese rubies, and the crowd in the square is clamoring for their confiscation to reimburse his victims. But the scoundrel and his allies at court have made a convincing case that at least some of his wealth was obtained legitimately, and through good service to the crown. The king ponders for a minute and announces his judgment. Because there’s no way to know which portion of the rubies 
were bought with ill-gotten wealth, the fine will be determined through 
a game of wits between the merchant and the king’s most clever advisor – you. You’re both told the rules in advance. The merchant will be allowed to
discreetly divide his rubies among three boxes, which
will then be placed in front of you. You will be given three cards, and must write a number 
between 1 and 30 on each, before putting a card in
front of each of the boxes. The boxes will then all be opened. For each box, you will receive exactly as many rubies as the number written
on the corresponding card, if the box has that many. But if your number is greater than 
the number of rubies actually there, the scoundrel gets to keep the entire box. The king puts just two constraints on how
the scoundrel distributes his rubies. Each box must contain at least two rubies and one of the boxes must contain 
exactly six more rubies than another— but you won’t know which boxes those are. After a few minutes of deliberation, the merchant hides the gems, 
and the boxes are brought in front of you. Which numbers should you choose in order to guarantee the largest possible
fine for the scoundrel and the greatest compensation 
for his victims? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 You don’t want to overshoot
by being too greedy. But there is a way you can guarantee to get more than half of the scoundrel’s 
stash. The situation resembles an 
adversarial game like chess – only here you can’t see the 
opponent’s position. To figure out the minimum number of rubies
you’re guaranteed to win, you need to look for the worst case
scenario, as if the merchant already knew your move and could arrange the rubies 
to minimize your winnings. Because you have no way of knowing which
boxes will have more or fewer rubies, you should pick the same number for each. Suppose you write three 9’s. The scoundrel might have allocated the
rubies as 8, 14 and 8. In that case, you’d receive 9 from the
middle box and no others. On the other hand, you can be
sure that at least two boxes have a minimum of 8 rubies. Here’s why. We’ll start by assuming the opposite, that two boxes have 7 or fewer. Those could not be the two that 
differ by 6, because every box must have 
at least 2 rubies. In that case, the third box would have at
most 13 rubies—that’s 7 plus 6. Add up all three of those boxes, and the most that could equal is 27. Since that’s less than 30, this scenario isn’t possible. You now know, by what’s called
a proof by contradiction, that two of the boxes have 
8 or more rubies. If you ask for 8 from all three boxes you’ll receive at least 16— and that’s the best you can guarantee, as you can see by thinking again
about the 8, 14, 8 scenario. You’ve recovered more than half the 
scoundrel’s fortune as restitution for the public. And though he’s managed to hold
on to some of his rubies, his fortune has definitely 
lost some of its shine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In this puzzle, your strategy is a balance between not asking for too little and not asking for too much. Why?
Options: A. If you ask for too little, the scoundrel will think you're a fool. If you ask for too much, you might not get anything, B. If you ask for too little, you’ll get only a little. If you ask for too much, the scoundrel will think you're a fool, C. If you ask for too little, you’ll get only a little. If you ask for too much you might not get anything
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main goal of the game described in the transcript? Options: A. To guess the exact number of rubies in each box, B. To guarantee the largest possible fine for the scoundrel, C. To determine the legitimacy of the merchant's wealth, D. To win all the rubies for oneself Correct Option: B
Question 2: How many boxes will the merchant discreetly divide his rubies among? Options: A. 2 boxes, B. 3 boxes, C. 4 boxes, D. 5 boxes Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the minimum number of rubies that each box must contain? Options: A. 1 ruby, B. 2 rubies, C. 3 rubies, D. 4 rubies Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the worst-case scenario for the player's winnings? Options: A. Winning all 30 rubies, B. Winning 20 rubies, C. Winning less than 20 rubies, D. Winning 9 rubies Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the minimum number of rubies the player is guaranteed to win if they write three 9's on the cards? Options: A. 0 rubies, B. 1 ruby, C. 9 rubies, D. 10 rubies Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, why is the scenario of two boxes having 7 or fewer rubies not possible? Options: A. Because the third box would have more than 13 rubies, B. Because the two boxes with 7 or fewer rubies cannot be the ones that differ by 6, C. Because the total number of rubies would be less than 30, D. Because the player would win all the rubies Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the result of the proof by contradiction mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. Two boxes have 7 or fewer rubies, B. Two boxes have 8 or more rubies, C. Three boxes have 9 or more rubies, D. All boxes have the same number of rubies Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the best the player can guarantee to win, according to the transcript? Options: A. At least 15 rubies, B. At least 16 rubies, C. At least 20 rubies, D. At least 25 rubies Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the scenario in which the player would receive 9 rubies from the middle box and no others? Options: A. The merchant allocated 8, 8, and 8 rubies among the boxes, B. The merchant allocated 8, 14, and 8 rubies among the boxes, C. The merchant allocated 10, 10, and 10 rubies among the boxes, D. The merchant allocated 12, 12, and 12 rubies among the boxes Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the result of the player's strategy of writing three 9's on the cards? Options: A. The player wins all 30 rubies, B. The player wins at least 16 rubies, C. The player wins less than 16 rubies, D. The player wins 9 rubies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ exactly. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 4 is the closest match, but it's still not very similar.

A better-generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ would be:

Question: Why is it important to balance your strategy in this puzzle?
Options: A. If you ask for too little, the scoundrel will think you're a fool. If you ask for too much, you might not get anything, B. If you ask for too little, you’ll get only a little. If you ask for too much, the scoundrel will think you're a fool, C. If you ask for too little, you’ll get only a little. If you ask for too much you might not get anything

Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main goal of the game described in the transcript? Options: A. To guess the exact number of rubies in each box, B. To guarantee the largest possible fine for the scoundrel, C. To determine the legitimacy of the merchant's wealth, D. To win all the rubies for oneself Correct Option: B
Question 2: How many boxes will the merchant discreetly divide his rubies among? Options: A. 2 boxes, B. 3 boxes, C. 4 boxes, D. 5 boxes Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the minimum number of rubies that each box must contain? Options: A. 1 ruby, B. 2 rubies, C. 3 rubies, D. 4 rubies Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the worst-case scenario for the player's winnings? Options: A. Winning all 30 rubies, B. Winning 20 rubies, C. Winning less than 20 rubies, D. Winning 9 rubies Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the minimum number of rubies the player is guaranteed to win if they write three 9's on the cards? Options: A. 0 rubies, B. 1 ruby, C. 9 rubies, D. 10 rubies Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, why is the scenario of two boxes having 7 or fewer rubies not possible? Options: A. Because the third box would have more than 13 rubies, B. Because the two boxes with 7 or fewer rubies cannot be the ones that differ by 6, C. Because the total number of rubies would be less than 30, D. Because the player would win all the rubies Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the result of the proof by contradiction mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. Two boxes have 7 or fewer rubies, B. Two boxes have 8 or more rubies, C. Three boxes have 9 or more rubies, D. All boxes have the same number of rubies Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the best the player can guarantee to win, according to the transcript? Options: A. At least 15 rubies, B. At least 16 rubies, C. At least 20 rubies, D. At least 25 rubies Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the scenario in which the player would receive 9 rubies from the middle box and no others? Options: A. The merchant allocated 8, 8, and 8 rubies among the boxes, B. The merchant allocated 8, 14, and 8 rubies among the boxes, C. The merchant allocated 10, 10, and 10 rubies among the boxes, D. The merchant allocated 12, 12, and 12 rubies among the boxes Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the result of the player's strategy of writing three 9's on the cards? Options: A. The player wins all 30 rubies, B. The player wins at least 16 rubies, C. The player wins less than 16 rubies, D. The player wins 9 rubies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the smallest number that the player could ask for from each box that would result in receiving nothing. This question is related to the strategy and outcome of the game.

Among the generated MCQs, Question 5 is the closest in terms of content, as it asks about the minimum number of rubies the player is guaranteed to win if they write three 9's on the cards. However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it does not ask about the smallest number that would result in receiving nothing.

Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ closely. If I had to choose, I would say that Question 5 is the most similar, but it's still not a good match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the kingdom’s
most prosperous merchants has been exposed for his corrupt dealings. Nearly all of his riches are invested in a collection of 30 exquisite Burmese rubies, and the crowd in the square is clamoring for their confiscation to reimburse his victims. But the scoundrel and his allies at court have made a convincing case that at least some of his wealth was obtained legitimately, and through good service to the crown. The king ponders for a minute and announces his judgment. Because there’s no way to know which portion of the rubies 
were bought with ill-gotten wealth, the fine will be determined through 
a game of wits between the merchant and the king’s most clever advisor – you. You’re both told the rules in advance. The merchant will be allowed to
discreetly divide his rubies among three boxes, which
will then be placed in front of you. You will be given three cards, and must write a number 
between 1 and 30 on each, before putting a card in
front of each of the boxes. The boxes will then all be opened. For each box, you will receive exactly as many rubies as the number written
on the corresponding card, if the box has that many. But if your number is greater than 
the number of rubies actually there, the scoundrel gets to keep the entire box. The king puts just two constraints on how
the scoundrel distributes his rubies. Each box must contain at least two rubies and one of the boxes must contain 
exactly six more rubies than another— but you won’t know which boxes those are. After a few minutes of deliberation, the merchant hides the gems, 
and the boxes are brought in front of you. Which numbers should you choose in order to guarantee the largest possible
fine for the scoundrel and the greatest compensation 
for his victims? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 You don’t want to overshoot
by being too greedy. But there is a way you can guarantee to get more than half of the scoundrel’s 
stash. The situation resembles an 
adversarial game like chess – only here you can’t see the 
opponent’s position. To figure out the minimum number of rubies
you’re guaranteed to win, you need to look for the worst case
scenario, as if the merchant already knew your move and could arrange the rubies 
to minimize your winnings. Because you have no way of knowing which
boxes will have more or fewer rubies, you should pick the same number for each. Suppose you write three 9’s. The scoundrel might have allocated the
rubies as 8, 14 and 8. In that case, you’d receive 9 from the
middle box and no others. On the other hand, you can be
sure that at least two boxes have a minimum of 8 rubies. Here’s why. We’ll start by assuming the opposite, that two boxes have 7 or fewer. Those could not be the two that 
differ by 6, because every box must have 
at least 2 rubies. In that case, the third box would have at
most 13 rubies—that’s 7 plus 6. Add up all three of those boxes, and the most that could equal is 27. Since that’s less than 30, this scenario isn’t possible. You now know, by what’s called
a proof by contradiction, that two of the boxes have 
8 or more rubies. If you ask for 8 from all three boxes you’ll receive at least 16— and that’s the best you can guarantee, as you can see by thinking again
about the 8, 14, 8 scenario. You’ve recovered more than half the 
scoundrel’s fortune as restitution for the public. And though he’s managed to hold
on to some of his rubies, his fortune has definitely 
lost some of its shine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If we allow a box to contain zero rubies, but still require one box to contain 6 more rubies than another, then how many rubies should you ask for from each box and how many could you guarantee to get in total?
Options: A. 7,14, B. 8,16, C. 13,13, D. 6,12
Correct Option: D

Because the two boxes with 7 or fewer rubies cannot be the ones that differ by 6, C. Because the total number of rubies would be less than 30, D. Because the player would win all the rubies Correct Option: B
